content.blockHeader: Study compositions: Period/sentence and small ternary form (M 34–42, M 29–31, M 45–46)
blockContent: The ink drafts of the study compositions M 34–42, which are notated on a single folio, probably date from the very beginning of Webern’s studies and can therefore be dated to around November 1904. We can tell that these are indeed composition exercises because these ink drafts contain numerous annotations in pencil that outline a correction or a variant, or that use signs to mark certain problematic passages that were presumably intended to be revised. These very first exercises allow us to observe the learning principle of incremental forms very clearly; they represent the first stages of development in Webern’s engagement with sentence, period, and then – in a seamless transition – ternary form.

It is especially interesting how Webern, almost from the very start, experiments with irregularities in formal and harmonic structure. Whereas M 34 is still based on a regularly structured period with a four-measure antecedent and a four-measure consequent, M 35 already formulates a nine­measure period whose antecedent comprises five measures and at the same time excludes the actual dominant, ending instead on the dominant of the consequent that turns initially to the parallel minor.

The number of measures increases across the subsequent individual exercises, and the different sections of the periods almost always reveal an asymmetrical relationship in their number of measures. In addition, the melodic line often blurs the underlying metre (such as by using ties across bar lines in M 36, M 37, M 40 and M 41). From M 36 onwards, these exercises shift into ternary forms that try out, for example, different possibilities for recapitulation:

M 35/42shortened antecedent, consequent of the same length with subsequent coda
M 36only the antecedent
M 37only a varied antecedent
M 38varied antecedent with unaltered consequent
M 39 v1antecedent with transposed closing formula from the consequent
M 39 v2antecedent combined with varied, slightly shortened consequent
M 40antecedent unaltered, consequent shortened by one measure
M 41antecedent and consequent varied and expanded

Webern also seeks varied solutions in his middle sections, where he primarily experiments with formal length and tries out his harmonic options (variant keys or parallel keys, major/minor mediants, or introducing the dominant or subdominant via the minor variant).

The study composition M 42 is especially revealing for Schoenberg’s teaching methodology because it is obviously a later addition to M 35 and was notated on a separate sheet. It comprises a middle section and a repeat of the A section for M 35, thereby documenting for the first time in Webern’s studies Schoenberg’s step-by-step approach in which he engaged with forms of increasing size by means of individual formal sections.23 In order to emphasize the connection between these two sections that were notated separately, M 35 and M 42 are combined into a single unit in the present edition.

The next study compositions, M 29–31, are comparatively conventional in formal terms and in part almost symmetrical (see the repetition of the A section in M 29). However, a comparison shows that they also exhibit new formal and harmonic aspects and are at the same time more extensive and more elaborate. It is therefore conceivable that they were composed immediately after the previous exercises and thus date from roughly the end of 1904.

M 30 and M 31 are notated on the recto and verso of a single sheet and follow the model for the period. In M 30, Webern for the first time chooses a 6/8 metre, while its key of A-flat major has more accidentals than his previous study compositions. He also increasingly explores his harmonic possibilities by initially avoiding the dominant in the A section, choosing instead the sixth degree (the parallel minor). In the middle section, the chordal progressions generally move in half-measures; Webern also touches on the variant key of a-flat minor (i). In the repeat of the A section, the dominant is excluded until shortly before the close, and at the point analogous to the initial A section (measure 19) it is initially replaced by a sixth chord of the minor variant (v). In contrast, M 31 has an uneven, eleven-measure period structure in its antecedent and consequent, which flow smoothly one into the other. Its direct confrontation of C major and B major is striking, the latter functioning as an intermediate dominant to the domi­nant parallel minor, e minor (iii), whose major variant (III{{ref.getGlyph('[#]')}}) is important in the middle section. The recapitulation (5 + 4 measures) reorganizes the motivic components and concludes with a short coda that is very similar to that of M 42. In M 29, Webern departs from the period model for the first time and formulates a sentence that leads to vi. The subsequent middle section with its many harmonic roots (what Schoenberg called “Stufenreichtum”) takes on the distinct character of a development section.* Since M 30 and M 31 form a period, whereas M 45 and M 46 subsequently fall back on the model of the sentence, it is possible that M 29, which is notated on a separate leaf, could actually have been composed after M 30–31. It is noteworthy that the sketches for the beginning of M 29 are relatively detailed, and they demonstrate how Webern was trying to engage in the melodic development of the motif.

In the two study compositions M 45 and M 46, the piano writing becomes more complex and the three-part form is expanded. We can see that Webern has taken greater care here, not least in assigning a greater number of dynamic and agogic markings. It is also possible that he wrote these pieces at the same time as his initial exercises for string quartet, as the first three-part forms for this ensemble (M 26–28) are found on the same manuscript sheets.

The opening of M 45 is strongly reminiscent of the start of the first theme from Richard Wagner’s&ngsp;Siegfried Idyll (the melodic line has been slightly altered and shifted upwards by a major second). In version 1, the A section, which is based on an asymmetrical sentence (18 measures: 3 + 3 + 3 + 2 and 3 + 4),24 is for the first time divided into two sections. After a half-cadence with a fermata, the varied main theme follows in the tonic. The contrasting middle section on the mediant develops motifs from the theme and its variant in a complementary manner before leading into a much-shortened recapitulation (9 measures) that brings the main theme only as a reminiscence, and concludes with a fleeting motivic synthesis.

The formal imbalance that results from attaching little importance to the recapitulation might have prompted Schoenberg to have his pupil recast the structure (this seems to be indicated by the various annotations and insertions as well sweeping deletions in pencil). In any case, the proportions of the A-B-A structure appear more balanced in version 2 of M 45, where Webern moves the varied main theme to the beginning of the recapitulation, extends the coda, which now brings a reminiscence of the varied theme, and adds closing sections as a new element.

In formal terms, M 46 is incomplete. However, it seems clear that the A section should be given once more at the end as a recapitulation, which would similarly result in a ternary structure. In version 1, Webern also marked out eight measures (13–20) but left them empty. He was obviously aware of how much he ought to compose before the middle section: as in version 2, he intended inserting a repetition of the main theme in the upper octave. The A section of the ternary form thus itself has a subordinate a-b-a form,25 the middle section of which Webern extended by two measures in version 2 of M 46. Otherwise, the differences between the two versions mainly concern the B section, whose harmony and figurations are highly reminiscent of Franz Schubert (e. g. his “Trauerwalzer” D 365, No. 2, also known as the “Sehnsuchtswalzer”), and whose harmonic progressions are made more complex in the revised version.26

The first performance of the study compositions for piano M 34–42 (together with study compositions M 43–44) was given in Switzerland by Jean-Jacques Dünki on 12 August 1988 on the occasion of the “5th Musical Encounters at Lenzburg Castle”, using his own transcriptions.27 The study compositions M 45–46, together with study compositions M 32–33, M 22–23 (M 22 without the variations for string quartet), M 75–76, M 116 and the piano pieces M 158–159, M 266 and M 280 (which have only survived in sketches and remain fragments), were also given their first performances by Dünki, this time at a concert at Château d’Autigny near Fribourg on 13 September 1998. He again played from his own transcriptions. He had already recorded all these pieces the previous April.28

blockContent: Webern’s exercises in writing for the piano and for string quartet apparently began to run in parallel, at the latest from the moment when he started to practise scherzo form in his lessons. M 32 is the only scherzo for piano that has survived from his student days and was written in close chronological proximity to the Scherzo with Trio for string quartet, M 68. Based on the arrangement of the sketches in the manuscripts, we may even assume that M 32 was composed after M 68, meaning that Webern’s first essay in this form was a work for chamber ensemble.

Webern took the impulsive main theme in E major of M 32 from his song “Nachtgebet der Braut” M 12, which he composed in April 1903.29 Its storm-and-stress spirit points to Richard Strauss as a possible model.30 The shift in genre from the relative freedom of song to a more tightly organized instrumental piece might have been suggested by Schoenberg himself for didactic reasons,31 and it certainly required a greater focus in its formal and motivic aspects. The Scherzo M 32 is based on a symmetrical period that culminates in a small, final group and is in a harmonically stable E major. The contrasting middle section, which proceeds in textbook fashion with sequences and motivic set pieces that are successively shortened, is divided into a modulating section and a more episodic section in f-sharp minor / A major that finally leads into a varied recapitulation.

The manuscript contains a number of deletions and instructions for revision in pencil and brown crayon (e. g. “theme below”, “counter-voice above”) whose handwriting cannot always be attributed clearly to either Webern or Schoenberg, but which we can trace on the basis of the subsequent versions and the inserted passages that were noted on separate sheets.

Version 2 of M 32 contains only a few changes that are mostly limited to the modulating passage in the B section. The internal motivic structure and the harmony are essentially retained. Webern is primarily concerned with tightening the somewhat incoherent transition to f-sharp minor / A major (the measures 45–48 from version 1 that were deleted lacked a motivic reference to the main theme).

The reduction to 21 measures in the modulation remains in version 3, but from the second half onwards (measure 30), Webern abandons the chord sequences in fifths interspersed with half-diminished seventh chords (which perhaps seemed harmonically too monotonous) in favour of a modulation to the distant key of E-flat major in order to arrive finally at the episode in f-sharp minor via an enharmonic shift. The transition into the recapitulation is now more focussed, being shortened from eight to three measures. Webern also abandons the accompaniment with broken chords in the recapitulation, instead notating a simpler, but fuller texture.

It is only indirectly apparent that M 33 could function as a contrasting trio to the scherzo M 32. However, several aspects suggest that they belong together in formal terms: (1) both versions of M 33 were notated directly below the final measures of M 32, version 1; (2) they stand in close chronological proximity to the study composition for string quartet M 68 in which the trio is called thus; (3) M 33 is in the parallel key of e minor; (4) the melody in both M 32 and M 33 begins on the third; (5) both have recourse to a dotted rhythm with an accompaniment featuring a quaver rest followed by broken chords in quavers.32 The two versions of M 33 differ only slightly in melodic and harmonic terms.

The study compositions for piano M 32–33, together with the study compositions M 45–46, M 22–23, M 75–76, M 116 and the piano pieces M 158–159, M 266 and M 280 (which have only survived in sketches and remain fragments) were given their first performances by Jean-Jacques Dünki in a concert at Château d’Autigny near Fribourg on 13 September 1998. He played from his own transcriptions, and had already made a recording of these study compositions in the April of that same year.

content.blockHeader: Study compositions: Theme with variations (M 22–23, M* 409–410, M* 412–416)
blockContent: When it comes to variations, Webern’s exercises for piano and for string quartet are even more closely intertwined than is the case with his scherzos. In both M 22 and M 23, his variations move seamlessly from a piano context to a string quartet – the difference being that with M 22, Webern consistently gives his 23 variations Roman numerals to the end, thus signalling a direct connection between them, whereas in M 23 he begins a new numbering for the variations for string quartet (which is probably why Moldenhauer declared them to be separate, numbering them M 24). For this reason, the last three variations of M 22 are included in the present edition despite their divergent instrumentation, whereas M 24 will appear in Section II/2b.

Initially, Webern and Schoenberg seem to have searched for a suitable theme together that did not contain “too many and too interesting features”.33 The first manuscript page of the ink draft of M 22 lists four potential themes, one below the other: M* 409, M* 410, M* 412 and the theme of M 22, which is in third place. The first two variations of M 22 begin immediately below the last notated theme, M* 412. The four variation themes pursue different formal and harmonic strategies:

The themes of M 22 and M* 412 (the latter initially consisting of only eight measures) are bracketed in pencil and assigned the Roman numerals I and II. Webern’s task was thus probably to compose a set each of variations on a shorter theme and a longer theme, beginning with the former.

The theme of M 22 in a minor is notable for its striking rhythmic contours and is similar in character to the well-known Caprice No. 24 by Niccolò Paganini. Their first four measures are almost identical in their harmonic disposition. Webern’s subsequent variations operate primarily with a rhythmic and melodic elaboration of the theme, while the basic chord progressions are retained (except for the few variations that have survived in fragmentary form) until the thirteenth variation. Here, for the first time, Webern diverges from the initial constellation by closing the antecedent with a cadence on III in C major and opening the consequent on the dominant V instead. It is notable that this change occurs just as Webern is developing further potential variation themes. In the ink draft of M 22, further sketches for variation themes M* 413 and M* 414 are inserted between variations XII and XIII.34

These try out other harmonic strategies that are reflected in the subsequent variations of M 22. The harmonic divergence found in variation XIII is anticipated in M* 413 (though this only comprises seven measures), where III in the major – albeit already in the third measure – is reached by means of the same progression, i-(V)-III. The modulation to the parallel minor as found in M* 414 is carried out by Webern in a similar manner in the major variations Nos. XIV (fragment) and XVIII. The counterpart to this, namely a shift into the parallel major from the minor mode, can be found in variations XVII and XX, where new harmonic nuances can be observed.
Two more possible themes for variations, M* 415 and M* 416, have been inserted before variation XIX.

These are followed by the last two variations in piano score. Their harmonic scheme corresponds to that of the initial theme, with a single minor divergence in the very last variation. However, Webern seems to take up the syncopation from M* 416 that had not appeared anywhere else before now. Finally, in the three variations for string quartet, the instrumentation enables Webern to employ new compositional techniques such as motivic fragmentation and canonic entries. The chord progressions are in line with his hitherto approach: first the basic structure is retained (variation XXI), then it becomes freer (variations XXII, XXIII).

This dynamic in the compositional process of M 22, with its repeated interweaving of variations and variation themes in the manuscript, ultimately provides us with an exemplary snapshot of the teaching dynamic: there is a constant process of analysing and thinking ahead while Webern composes, obtaining feedback from his teacher while exploring possible room for manoeuvre.

Even before the last variation of M 22 for string quartet, Webern notes yet another theme, but this time it is not one of his own. It is the German folk song “Der Winter ist vergangen” (“Winter is past”)35 with his own harmonization of it. This 16-measure model served as the starting point for his variations M 23 and M 24, apparently replacing M* 412 that had originally been intended for this exercise.36 Webern notated this theme twice, in ink, with different harmonizations, though with only slight changes the second time; the modifications to its second measure are the ones that seem the most worthy of note. Here, Webern prolongs the shift to the minor in the harmonies by using minor chords inherent to the key of G major in the second half of the measure. The first phrase ends not on I but on vi, thus in e minor (this is not the case at the parallel place in the recapitulation, where it is brought forward to the second beat of measure 9. The variations continue this alternation between e minor and G major with varying results). The final crotchet of measure 2 is now harmonized on ii, a minor, whereas Webern had previously employed IV, namely the subdominant, C major. This is clearly C major, despite the absence of the fifth (g), and is perceived as such not least because the note c is used as both the root and the melody note. By switching to a minor, Webern emphasizes the harmonic simplicity of the theme, whose harmonies are thus limited to the chords of I, ii, V and vi. Even in the subsequent variations, there are only a few sporadic exceptions to this repertoire of chords (e. g. variation II, measure 6). Because the theme has its own individual melodic character, in contrast to that of M 22, the principles of variation employed in M 23 focus instead on figurations, ornaments, rhythmic splitting and changes of register in the melodic line.

Variations M 22–23 were performed for the first time by Jean-Jacques Dünki on 13 September 1998 in a concert at the Château d’Autigny near Fribourg, together with study compositions M 45–46, M 32–33, M 75–76, M 116 and the piano pieces M 158–159, M 266 and M 280 that have only survived in sketches and remain fragments. Dünki played from his own transcriptions, and had already made a recording of these study compositions in April of that same year (including the alternative variation themes M* 409–410 and M* 412–416).

content.blockHeader: Study compositions: Phrase construction and harmonization (M* 465–467)
blockContent: In July 1906, when Webern was staying at his family’s country estate of Preglhof, he wrote what is today his earliest extant letter to Schoenberg, informing him that he was currently harmonizing a chorale a day. He also asked Schoenberg how he was supposed to solve the task that he had apparently set his students: “Am I just to harmonize the chorales or do I also have to treat them contrapuntally? I understood that I was to work out the chorale melodies in a manner similar to the chorales in the ‘St Matthew Passion’, in four voices with a few passing notes. What Horwitz assumes, however, is that they should be done in the manner of Bach’s chorale preludes: in one voice the chorale, in the others canons or developments of one or more themes.”37 Schoenberg’s answer has not survived, but Webern’s archives in fact contain both types of chorale arrangement mentioned here. We also find further study exercises in the corresponding manuscripts, mixed together with the sketches for these chorales and chorale preludes, and which must therefore have been written at the same time. These exercises, all of which are eight measures long, seem to have focussed on two aspects in particular: constructing a phrase from various motif forms, rather as if using a set of building blocks, and harmonizing the resultant phrase in a kind of Kantionalsatz (a type of four-part writing with a note-against-note accompaniment to the melody). This building-block principle is several times reflected in Webern’s marginal notes on his manuscript paper, where he lists the possible combinations of his motifs in tabular form (e. g. “aab | aba | abb | aab”).

In light of the fact that Webern was already at quite an advanced stage of his composition tuition, these exercises may initially seem surprising. In the early chapters of his Fundamentals, Schoenberg himself mentions the principle of “connecting motive-forms”, but nevertheless observes that: “artistically, the connexion of motive-forms depends on factors which can only be discussed at a later stage.”38

In Webern’s manuscripts, the sketches for this exercise model extend over several pages in varying metres and keys. Webern wrote out three of them neatly in ink, M* 465–467, and clearly presented them to Schoenberg, as is obvious from their annotations in blue crayon. All three models are essentially based on the rhythmic motif of a dotted crotchet, then a quaver followed by two crotchets (a). The initial building blocks (aaab/aaab) are first slightly varied (abab/aaab) and then expanded (acab/aacb), with the different forms of the motif either related to each other or derived from one another. The variety of the underlying harmony is notable, as it features chords on almost all the degrees of the scale. Schoenberg’s critical annotations on these study compositions are aimed at the harmony and voice-leading, and above all he points out the obvious parallel fifths (which are in fact astonishingly frequent, e. g. in measures 1–2 in M* 465).

content.blockHeader: Study compositions: preparing for larger formal models? (M 75–76, M 43–44, M 116)
blockContent: Study compositions M 75–76,39 M 43–44 and M 116 are exercises that in part give the impression that Webern is resorting to a “simpler” form from earlier in his studies with Schoenberg, though its contours have now been softened and at the same time it employs harmony that is considerably more advanced. It is possible that one of Schoenberg’s didactic aims was to get Webern to apply the formal thinking he had learnt in a compositionally more complex context, and to use the material created in the process as the starting point for larger forms.

Augmented chords, enharmonic shifts and chromatic progressions make the tonality here more ambivalent, and functional harmonic tension is sometimes abandoned altogether. Webern’s occasional use of “simultaneous notation” is notable here, as it was first described by Reinhard Gerlach in the case of the Dehmel song “Am Ufer” M 130 from 1908,40 and which can also be found in several of his George songs (see e. g. “Erwachen aus dem tiefsten Traumesschoße” M 143, “Kunfttag I” M 144 and “Trauer I” M 145 in AWG I/5). The chordal displacements are divided up linearly according to the basic metrical unit (M 44: measures 1–2, M 76: measures 14–17), which means that the smaller note values enable Webern to have visual control over the individual chords. The compositional process is thus directly reflected in the musical text. The homorhythmic chord sequences in M 116 (measure 13) and especially in M 43 can also be seen as an expression of these experiments with harmonic connections.

In certain places in these exercises, Webern’s formal and harmonic models remain recognisable as blueprints, though they tend to be dissolved or raise questions. In M 44, M 76 and M 116 (the last of which has a greatly shortened recapitulation), the ternary structure still appears distinct, and the underlying harmonic scheme is largely conventional. In contrast, however, the formal interfaces in M 75 are less immediately apparent. Assuming that this is indeed a ternary form: Where exactly does the contrasting B section begin in M 75? (at measure 7, with the upbeat?), and should a concluding formal section A' actually follow after the double bar line? Finally, in the case of M 43, the question arises as to whether this is a ternary form at all, or whether we are here dealing with a more extended thematic exposition that would then lead into a second subject.

content.blockHeader: Study compositions: Rondo form and sonata movement (M 113, M 114, M 112)
blockContent: It was Moldenhauer who first suggested that the three study compositions M 112–114 might have been intended to form a three-movement sonata cycle – an idea subsequently taken up by others.42 However, as Cox has already observed,43 this assumption is hardly plausible in view of Schoenberg’s conception of form. In fact, these three study compositions seem to document Webern’s exploration of sonata form and rondo form, notated in piano score. Their chronological order cannot be completely determined, though it becomes clear from the source material that M 114 must have been composed after M 113, as sketches for M 114 can be found in the staves underneath the incomplete ink draft of M 113 after it breaks off. The first sketches for M 113 can in turn be found in the manuscripts for study composition M 78 for string quartet (Langsamer Satz) to which Webern gave the date of June 1905, and which is also in rondo form. This naturally offers us merely the earliest possible date for M 113, for which a date of summer/autumn 1905 is conceivable.

According to Schoenberg’s methodology, it would seem natural to situate M 113 before M 112 because the latter is a sonata movement whereas the former is a rondo, indeed a “large Rondo form” in Schoenberg’s terminology, with the structure ABA-C-ABA and corresponding transitions.44

The C section – here labelled “very delicately and very quick” – has the character of a trio in this formal model, and is often rather more “‘étude-like’”,45 which we can confirm here on account of the use of many sequences. The A section is itself structured once more as a small-scale aba form, which is referred to as a common practice by Schoenberg in his Fundamentals.46 In this respect, M 113 follows on seamlessly from the previous exercises, with Webern acquiring practical competence in larger forms on the basis of what he has learned previously.

On the harmonic level, Webern essentially contrasts the formal sections, and connects them, by means of mediant relationships. The b section shifts briefly from the home key of F major to A major, whereas in the B section the modulations begin in a minor, but in d minor in the recapitulation. The longer section, C, is in the submediant, D major. The Rondo M 113 ultimately remained a fragment. Both its sketches and the ink draft end with the B section of the recapitulation, meaning that the concluding A section is missing, as is any coda that Webern might have planned.47

The step-by-step manner in which Webern worked in larger forms can be seen almost paradigmatically in M 114, where the genesis of both form and content is directly intertwined. A total of six versions can be reconstructed from the ink drafts; one by one, Webern extends them with extra sections in his progress towards the overall goal of writing a larger-scale form.48 Webern obviously consulted with his teacher after each stage, which is why the individual versions contain numerous annotations in pencil and crayon that presumably document Schoenberg’s suggestions. This approach also explains a number of divergences in the notation across the various stages of the work (see e. g. the F6 on the third beat of measure 5 in versions 1–3 and of measures 119 and 125 in versions 5–6; however, measure 5 in versions 4–6 and measures 48 and 49 of versions 3–6 have G6).

The extant version in each case begins with a main theme (A) plus a transition, which is followed initially by a second theme (B), then a repetition of the main theme – which presents us with a three-part song form – and finally there is an episodic, development-like section before the form is completed with a recapitulation that subsequently also features the second theme.

The C' segment in particular is in formal terms ambivalent and has been interpreted in different ways. Kolneder and Cerha (both of whom write of an ABACABA form) and Shaftel and Wedler see the C' segment (measure 87 in text version 6) as the beginning of the recapitulation,49 whereas Cox believes that it rather belongs to the development-like section.50 In fact, C' is highly varied when compared to the exposition and does have the character of a development. This modulating section is conceived as a build-up of tension, and also takes up the quaver and triplet figures from the second theme. This means that we cannot speak of a clear recapitulation, neither in thematic nor in harmonic terms. In this respect, it is revealing how version 5 is changed by inserting the second theme in the tonic major, creating version 6. This insertion of the second theme (B), now in C major and notated on a separate leaf, lends more weight to the recapitulation, which was previously undis­tinguished. At the same time, it alleviates the previous harmonic imbalance on account of the second theme never appearing in the tonic at all.

With Schoenberg’s Fundamentals in mind here, it seems pertinent to use his formal model of what he called the “Great Sonata Rondo” to analyse M 114, as its structure ABA-CC'-ABA encompasses both a trio and a development section.51 The episodic section C, in C-flat major / a-flat minor, actually differs from C' in that it introduces new material and primarily operates using sequences, whereas C' draws on exposed motifs from the first and second themes and combines this material contrapuntally. Seen from this perspective, we do not have to assign C' any hybrid function (as a development/recapitulation), because the B section that begins in the tonic can be read as the beginning of an inverse recapitulation, BA(B/coda), especially since the coda is based motivically on the second section of the second theme, but also because the closing measures perform a temporal switch by first stating the second theme (at measure 150) and only then the principal theme (measure 156).

However, it remains uncertain as to what Webern’s formal intention was in the intermediate version 5: Was he already planning a “Great Sonata Rondo” at this point, albeit with a highly abbreviated, unbalanced recapitulation without the second subject, or did he perhaps still intend writing a large rondo as in the case of M 113, in which section C would assume the function of a trio, while the recapitulation is split into a tonal (C') recapitulation and a thematic (A) recapitulation?

In either case, Webern seems not to have determined the formal disposition of this piece from the start, which instead only emerged out of the compositional process itself, over the course of his lessons.52 Additional proof for this is to be found in the deletion of the original title “Sonatensatz” (“Sonata movement”), which was replaced in pencil by “Rondo”, though it is impossible to ascertain just when this change was made. However, it must surely be connected with versions 5 and 6, because the order of the manuscript sheets indicates that the title page was probably only made for version 4, when the beginning of the three-part form had already been finalized. It is therefore somewhat astonishing that Webern planned to write a sonata­form movement after having drafted a ternary form, both because a ternary form seems better suited to becoming the exposition of a rondo, and because Schoenberg’s Fundamentals in fact reject the possibility of constructing a sonata-form movement in this way.53

The rondo M 114 has been published twice by Carl Fischer of New York since being discovered in Webern’s archives. The first time was by Hans Moldenhauer in 1966 (with a further issue in 1969), the second by Matthew R. Shaftel in 2014.54 Both editions make minor changes, especially with a view to practical performance (such as adding legato slurs and dynamic indications). And both present a text that is a mixture of the versions 5 and 6 presented here. However, Shaftel made numerous enharmonic changes, obviously to make the harmonic structure more conventional, and these are not unproblematic.
In formal terms, M 112 is clear – it is a classical sonata movement with a second subject in two parts – but the uncertain source situation presents us with some philological difficulties.

Two ink drafts have survived in Webern’s hand that contain specific sections: Version 1 offers an initial version of the first subject without the subsequent transition, while version 2 contains the development section up to the beginning of the recapitulation, though the last measures, where he begins to develop the second subject, are notated only fleetingly and incompletely. In this case, however, Webern’s focus was perhaps less on any progressive engagement with larger-scale form (as was the case with M 114) and more on grappling with a specific compositional problem. Webern’s sketches for M 112 are by far the most extensive among his piano pieces, and demonstrate that he was struggling with the development section in particular. A substantial number of these sketches are concerned with this formal section and the question of which themes and motifs should be developed. At times, the second part of the second subject plays a more significant role. Webern was engaged in a process of searching and beginning again, as is evident on account of the number of signs that he added, referring to other sketches on the page. This reveals a certain sense of insecurity that is not discernible to a similar extent in the other pieces considered here. It could explain why Webern made an ink draft of the development section – presumably so that he could present it separately to Schoenberg – despite his having at this point already sketched out the exposition including the second subject. This meant that he could already have made a complete copy of the movement from its beginning to the end of the development.

Webern must surely have then taken the next logical step of producing a complete version of this movement, though no such copy is extant today. A manuscript copy made by Webern’s early biographer Friedrich Wildgans has also been lost but has at least survived in several photocopies. Webern’s daughter Amalie Waller presumably lent the autograph to Wildgans in 1954,55 though it was apparently no longer to be found when Moldenhauer first published this sonata movement with Carl Fischer in 1966 and 1970.56

We can only speculate about just how accurately Wildgans copied Webern’s manuscript, and to what degree Webern had actually completed the piece at all. The autograph draft on which version 1 of M 112 is based contains several annotations in pencil suggesting that Webern had undertaken a considerable reorganization of his first theme, and which largely coincide with the instances where Wildgans’s copy diverges from the draft. However, there are also numerous inconsistencies between the two ink drafts and the sketches on the one hand, and Wildgans’s copy on the other, such as the divergent melodic line in measures 2 (see versions 1 and 3) and 94, which can hardly be explained away by suggesting that Wildgans might have been perfunctory in making his copy. These issues make one wonder just how advanced Webern’s version might have been that had served as Wildgans’s model.

In view of these findings, it seems somewhat absurd, if not in fact illusory, to try and reconstruct what might have constituted Webern’s original text, though this is what both Moldenhauer and Shaftel attempted in their editions that were published by Carl Fischer in 1966/1970 and 2014 respectively. Each of these editions constitutes a questionable compilation of the autograph manuscripts, Wildgans’s copy and the extant sketches, in order to produce a supposedly coherent musical text – Shaftel’s effort being even more questionable than Moldenhauer’s. The fact that neither of these editions features a complete critical report hardly makes them less problematic.

The first performance of the Rondo M 113 was given by Edwin Haugan on 5 February 1984 in Spokane (Washington) at a Rosaleen Moldenhauer Memorial Concert. The Sonata-Rondo M 114 had already been given its first performance by Noël Lee a few years earlier, on 2 August 1968 during the Fourth International Webern Festival at Dartmouth College in Hanover (New Hampshire). On 2 December 1958, in commemoration of Webern’s imminent 75th birthday, the pianist Else Stock-Hug gave the first performance of the sonata movement M 112 in the Schubert Hall of the Konzerthaus in Vienna.57

blockContent: A note made in green crayon on the fair copy, presumably after the fact, identifies this piano piece M 267 as a “Kinderstück” (“children’s piece”). It bears the date “(autumn 1924)”. In a letter of 3 January 1925 to the then director of Universal Edition, Emil Hertzka, Webern also refers to “children’s pieces that I have promised to write”.58 However, nothing more is known of any such agreement with UE. It is possible that the occasion was a publishing project initiated by Hertzka that envisaged compiling a collection of simple piano pieces for beginners. In any case, UE repeatedly published advertisements for works it commissioned from various composers that it described as “children’s pieces”.59

It is also indeed the case that Webern made several sketches for short piano pieces at about this time. Besides M 267, these include M 266, which was written shortly beforehand, is also entitled “Kinderstück”, and is dated autumn 1924; then there are M 277, “Im Tempo eines Menuetts” (“in the tempo of a minuet”),60 and M 280, both of which date from 1925. The upper margin of the manuscript for M 266 furthermore contains a list of various dances and formal types (fugue, canon, minuet, musette etc.) that has similarly been interpreted as a “project sketch” for a series of pieces for children.61

If Webern indeed became involved in this publishing project – for which there is no proof – then he undoubtedly did not complete his part of it. Only in the case of M 267, presented here, did he go beyond the sketching stage and make a fair copy in ink. However, this “children’s piece” ultimately also remained unpublished. As with M 114 and M 112, it was published posthumously by Carl Fischer: by Moldenhauer in 1966/67 and by Shaftel in 2014.62

M 267 is an interesting document for Webern’s development as a composer (despite the fact that its sketches are lost) because it is one of the first complete pieces that Webern composed using the twelve-tone technique. It thus offers us insights into his initial experiments with the new method. His earliest engagement with the technique developed by Schoenberg goes back to his sketches for various songs that he composed in 1922 in the context of his songs Op. 15 (Morgenlied, Op. 15/2 M 256, “Morgenglanz der Ewigkeit”, M 265 and “Mein Weg geht jetzt vorüber”, Op. 15/4 M 257).63 However, it was not until 1924 that Webern began to work consistently with the method.

The way in which Webern uses the twelve-tone technique in M 267 is simple and straightforward. Its note row, which is dominated by the interval of a minor second, is used only in its basic form. It is not subjected to any transpositions or inversions. The row is used a total of six times with only one instance of two row statements interlocking – namely at measure 14, at the fifth and sixth statements. Throughout the piece, Webern reduces the note values and increases the number of notes heard at any one time. This means in turn that the row is increasingly shortened, which brings about a dramatic intensification. As Shaftel has remarked, B flat is the only note that always sounds in the same octave (B4 flat) and signifies a kind of centre point, being a fifth away from the opening note (E flat) and the closing note (F) of the row.64 The closing measures take up the principle of the immediate repetition of notes that is already employed at the end of the first statement of the row, but that is this time spread over four octaves and is interrupted by a short semiquaver rest that serves to emphasize the final notes.

The Kinderstück M 267 was given its first performance on 22 July 1966 at a concert in a Stravinsky Festival of the New York Philharmonic in the Philharmonic Hall. It was played by the nine-year-old Caren Glasser.65

blockContent: The “text editions” of the study compositions for piano published in AWG Section II/2a are as a rule based on Webern’s ink drafts. In contrast to his sketches, which he usually made in pencil, these ink drafts tend to convey a state of completion during the work process, and presumably served as material for his lessons with Schoenberg. However, Webern’s use of ink to notate these pieces is neither a compelling nor a satisfactory criterion for us to regard them as deserving the status of “text editions”. Especially fragmentary or hasty drafts in ink can also be published as “sketch editions” (see, for example, the sketches for M 45 or M 114). Pieces written in pencil on the other hand are regarded as text editions when they have been notated with such care and in such detail that to regard them thus seems meaningful. Individual notes or measures notated in pencil in a draft that is otherwise in ink may also be included in a text edition in order to avoid confusing gaps in the musical text. These additions are given in small print in the present edition, to make them easily recognisable. However, these instances are to be regarded separately from those cases where Webern has refrained from notating certain formal sections (e.g. a repetition of a theme) simply to save time and effort. Such empty stretches, which occur occasionally in his study compositions, are left as they are in the text as edited here.

These study compositions were a product of Webern’s lessons. They accordingly contain many corrections and annotations in pencil and crayon, though these have not been included here in those cases where only one version of the musical text is extant. Instead, they are documented in the lists of corrections given in the online source descriptions. However, where two or more versions of a text are extant, then the corrections and annotations from the one version are adopted in the subsequent version insofar as they are clearly connected with the revisions to the latter. This procedure allows us to retain a greater degree of variance between the different versions of the text in question, even though the chronological order of the different steps of the revision process and of the use of different writing materials can rarely be determined with any clarity.

These study compositions are exercises, meaning that Webern did not have to complete them, neither compositionally nor in terms of their editorial format. We have therefore added a concluding bar line only to those compositions that were definitively completed. In the other cases, the bar line from the manuscript (whether single or double) has been left as it was. If an ending is obviously fragmentary – in other words, if a coherent compositional unit has been abandoned – then the last double stave on the right-hand side of the page is left open-ended in order to emphasise that the compositional exercise has been interrupted, for whatever reason.

Webern committed these study compositions to paper in a manner often perfunctory and incomplete. He was especially careless when it came to placing accidentals. The present edition has added those accidentals that are absent in the sources but are necessary, as well as accidentals that are required to clarify potentially ambiguous passages. Above and beyond this, we have also added cautionary accidentals to resolve or restore a specific pitch that had been altered in the previous measure. When accidentals are placed inconsistently across the different versions of a text, these have been left as they are, insofar as the different resultant possibilities are harmonically plausible. However, redundant accidentals have been removed without further comment, such as double accidentals ({{ref.getGlyph('[a]')}}{{ref.getGlyph('[b]')}}) or accidentals with­in ties.

When the diverging lines of a hairpin crescendo or decrescendo are of notably differing length, we have chosen one of the options before us and made both lines the same length without further comment.

Octaves that were erroneously notated as tenths (with too many ledger lines between the note heads) have been corrected and noted in the Critical Notes (Textkritische Anmerkungen). Occasionally, it happens that a single note in the lower staff of the piano is marked “8va”, despite it seeming unlikely that the note ought indeed to be displaced by an octave. The overall voice-leading in the left hand suggests that the lower octave should be added in such cases. For this reason, the passages in question have been notated here in octaves and are also listed in the Critical Notes.
